Award.AwardTitle: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: US-BRAZIL IRES / Analytical Applications of Nanomaterials and Microfluidic Devices
Award.AbstractNarration:
This collaborative project will facilitate a three-year international research experience for U.S. undergraduates majoring in STEM disciplines. Students from a diverse regional population will be recruited as summer cohorts to participate in research projects with researchers from the Brazilian Science-Technology Corridor (Sao Paulo - Campinas - Sao Carlos). The interest in analytical applications combining microfluidics and nanomaterials has grown exponentially in the last years. Considering these advances and their importance for future developments, this IRES program aims to provide the tools for students to develop the skills required to face an internationally competitive job market linked to chemical analysis. This proposal aims to boost education and training in a creative, multidisciplinary, and culturally-rich environment. A focus on minority recruiting, combined with the involvement of graduate students as mentors, will provide the support mechanisms required to expand and strengthen the pool of participants as well as the research experience.

Recent developments in nanotechnology and microfluidics have allowed the understanding and rational utilization of a series of micro total analysis systems (uTAS). The existing links between these two fields have enabled crossing the traditional borders and the development of unique training opportunities for students in science and engineering tracks. Furthermore, the interest in analytical applications combining microfluidics and nanomaterials has grown exponentially in the last years. Although this integration has enhanced sensing, separation, and extraction procedures, the applicability of specific nanomaterials for chemical analysis depends mainly on the chemical composition, structure, size, morphology, and preparation method. Considering these characteristics and their importance for future developments, this IRES program aims to provide students an enriching research experience and link chemical properties with a real-world analytical problem.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The interest in analytical applications combining microfluidics and nanomaterials has grown exponentially in the last years. Considering these advances and their importance for future developments, this IRES program aims to provide the tools for students (most of them undergrads) to develop the skills required to face an internationally-competitive job market linked to chemical analysis. This project aimed at boosting education and training in a creative, multidisciplinary, and culturally-rich environment.

  • The goal was to provide an international training experience to students and build upon the achievements of a current IRES program developed with the University of Sao Paulo ? Sao Carlos.
  • Project was directed by Dr. Garcia (UTSA, PI) and Dr. Gomez (CSULA, Co-PI) and locally coordinated by Dr. Carrilho (USP).
  • Project took advantage of recent development in Brazilian infrastructure and expand to include research topics and mentors in the Brazilian Science-Technology Corridor (Sao Paulo ? Campinas ? Sao Carlos, 240 km).
  • Project applied a series of tools already developed to promote the program, handle on-line applications, and monitor impact via traffic (Google Analytics).
  • A total of 18 participants were selected and allowed to choose between 3 locations and 8 potential projects (8 weeks).
  • Program included multiple pre-IRES trainings (microfluidics, nanomaterials, ethics, safety, culture, etc), career development activities, and financial assistance to attend a conference.
  • Post-IRES activities and on-line resources have been included to further maintain fluent communication between the participants/mentors/coordinators and increase the impact of the program.

 

The intellectual merit of the project resulted from the accomplishments of the participating faculty, who have a demonstrated commitment to develop the careers of emerging scientists from minority groups. Specifically, the program focused on developing highly trained undergraduates for careers in modern analytical chemistry (microfluidics, chemical analysis, and nanomaterials) via a comprehensive program that includes research, seminars, and workshops. Beyond the corresponding technical advancements, the project enabled a trans-cultural experience in a developing country. This experience included languages, food, and traditions.

 

Broader impacts. The project aimed to develop competent, confident, well-trained students ready to enter the workforce in STEM-based disciplines. A focus on minority recruiting, combined with the involvement of graduate students as mentors, provided the support mechanisms required to expand and strengthen the pool of participants as well as the research experience. Many of the participant students are now in the process of applying to grad school and have all reported significant changes in their view of other cultures.
